Valencia is the capital of Spain's Valencian Community (also known as the Valencian Country) and the third-largest city in Spain, after Madrid and Barcelona. It has approximately 800,000 inhabitants in its administrative center and is part of Spain's third-largest metropolitan area, with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million. The city serves as the capital of the autonomous community, which is the region's administrative and cultural hub.
Buffy Summers, a character portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.

Speech recognition (SR) is an interdisciplinary field within computational linguistics focused on developing technologies to convert spoken language into text. It integrates linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications include voice interfaces (e.g., voice dialing, call routing), data entry, document preparation, and aircraft systems. Advances are marked by a surge in academic research and widespread industry adoption of deep learning methods, with major companies like Google, Microsoft, and IBM leveraging these technologies in their systems.

Richard Alf (1952–2012) was an American businessman and comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970 as the Golden State Comic Book Convention, alongside Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry. He served as its chairman starting in 1970, and the event was later renamed the "San Diego Comic Book Convention."
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film *Fist of Fury*, which starred Bruce Lee as the lead character.

France's Dubuisson tied with South Africa's Van Zyl at 16 under par, while Rory McIlroy carded a 67 to reach 15 under par, sharing second with Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat. McIlroy, aiming for his first title since May, highlighted his consistent performance and expressed hope for a lower round. Despite a challenging start, including a three-putt and a putter-throw, he recovered with a birdie and eagle. The world number three missed several tournaments after an ankle injury in July but returned to compete in the PGA Tour, currently leading the Race to Dubai by 271 points with three events left. English players Chris Wood and Richard Bland dropped to fifth and seventh, respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman of al-Wefaq emphasized that meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain requires the government to present "concrete solutions" and highlighted divisions within the royal family, with Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa seen as a reformist amid hardliners opposing dialogue. He noted the 2011 seven-point plan for a constitutional monarchy, halted by GCC troop intervention, and criticized the UK and US for insufficient public pressure on Bahrain's government. Al-Wefaq continues advocating peaceful protests and demands the release of detained opposition leaders, asserting their inclusion is vital for dialogue success.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and key figure in the early-music movement, died in Cambridge after a months-long illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, leading it for 30 years and overseeing over 200 recordings, including the first complete Mozart symphony cycle on period instruments. His notable work includes the 1980 Handel's *Messiah* recording, hailed as a top all-time recording. Hogwood held prestigious roles, including artistic director of festivals and university positions, and was celebrated for his academic rigor, generosity, and influence on musicians. His funeral was private, with a memorial service to follow, and colleagues praised his legacy as a pioneer of historically informed performance.

In the year ending March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims, a decrease of five from the previous 12 months and the lowest since 1976, halving the figure from nine years prior. Sharp instruments, primarily knives, accounted for 51% of homicides (29 cases), with 31% of accused individuals under alcohol/drug influence. Only one 2015-16 case remained unresolved. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson highlighted sustained declines in violent crime but stressed continued efforts to address root causes, while Scottish Labour’s Claire Baker cautioned against complacency, noting revised upward revisions of 2014-15 figures and rising sexual and violent crimes.

Bournemouth (the Cherries) lost 2-1 to Sunderland, marking their first Premier League defeat to the Black Cats this season. Dan Gosling scored their sole goal, their first in three games. Manager Eddie Howe criticized the team's inability to convert chances, despite creating opportunities, and acknowledged the frustration of losing despite dominating possession. Sunderland's goals came from Victor Anichebe and Jermain Defoe's penalty, with Bournemouth failing to equalize even after Sunderland played with 10 men following Steven Pienaar's dismissal. Howe emphasized the need to move past the result.

The passage outlines Australia's policy of detaining boat migrants in offshore camps to prevent sea deaths, criticized by the *New York Times* as "brutal" and "inhumane." Prime Minister Abbott defended the approach, citing the Syrian child Alan Kurdi's death to emphasize stopping boat arrivals. He faced backlash for comparing ISIS to Nazis, which Jewish leaders deemed inappropriate due to the systematic nature of Nazi genocide versus ISIS terrorism. Abbott stood by his comments but avoided ranking evils. The policy's legality and ethics remain contentious.

The US suspended bilateral talks with Russia over Syria, blaming Russia and the Syrian government for escalating attacks on civilians in Aleppo, including strikes on a trauma hospital. Russia denied involvement in the aid convoy attack and accused the US of shifting responsibility for the truce's collapse. Aleppo has faced heavy bombardment since the ceasefire ended, with hundreds killed and 250,000 trapped in rebel-held areas. The US cited Russia's failure to prevent Syrian forces from targeting infrastructure and blocking aid, while Russia claimed the US failed to address humanitarian conditions and separate jihadist groups from moderates. Despite halting coordination talks, both sides agreed to continue counter-terrorism discussions to avoid clashes.

The passage discusses a Policy Exchange report backed by Downing Street, proposing that selling high-value vacant social homes could generate £4.5bn annually to build 80,000–170,000 social homes, aiming to address the housing crisis. The report argues this would create the largest social housing program since the 1970s, reducing the 1.8 million social housing waiting list by 500,000. However, Labour criticizes the plan, warning it could displace low-income families, exacerbate segregation, and undermine mixed communities. Critics, including the National Housing Federation and Labour MPs, argue the policy risks "cleansing" areas of working-class residents, while the government emphasizes council discretion and existing funding initiatives. The report defines "expensive social housing" as properties worth more than regional averages, totaling 816,000 units, with London holding over £70bn in such stock.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died in Swansea, a city experiencing a measles outbreak with 942 cases. His death's cause remains undetermined, with an inquest scheduled to await further tests. Since November, 83 people have been hospitalized. Colfer-Williams had recent asthma treatment and developed a rash before dying days after a GP visit. Public Health Wales confirmed measles but not the primary cause of death. His family is unsure how he contracted the disease, as no close contacts, including his vaccinated daughter, are infected.
Vincent Hudson, 54, of Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical sexual offense against a boy under 16, alleged to have occurred in 2001. He is due to appear at North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Gateshead and Guiseley drew 1-1 in a National League match. Guiseley led early via Jake Lawlor's goal (15'), but Gateshead equalized through Wes York (62') after a defensive error. Gateshead's team, managed by Neil Aspin, remained unbeaten in nine matches, while Guiseley, led by Adam Lockwood, extended their five-match unbeaten run. Key moments included saves by Guiseley's keeper Jonny Maxted and a yellow card for Gateshead's Gus Mafuta. The match report was supplied by the Press Association.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to replace two stadium stands to increase capacity, offering an alternative to the stalled Ashton Vale stadium project delayed by a town green application. The proposal, approved by Bristol City Council in November, requires a section 106 agreement and a six-week judicial review period. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown aims to start redevelopment in May 2024 if no judicial review is filed by March, providing clarity to supporters.

Cuadrilla suspended fracking in Lancashire after a 1.5-magnitude tremor, the second in two months, to review data from the British Geological Survey (BGS) before resuming operations. The BGS noted the latest quake shared a similar location and mechanism with a previous event, linking it to fracking activities. Fracking, which involves fracturing shale rocks to extract gas, has faced US environmental concerns over water contamination but is supported in the UK with strict regulation. The BGS monitors seismic activity, highlighting that fluid injection during fracking can induce earthquakes. Two small quakes have occurred since March 2023, with the latest 2km from the drilling site. Cuadrilla emphasized consulting experts, with analysis expected to take weeks.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old Liverpool piper with over 30 years of street performance experience, was found guilty of one fraud charge in April 2015 for using a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes, which he claimed was a tribute to victims rather than a fundraising tool. He was cleared of two other counts. The campaign's chairman confirmed Carpenter had permission to display the banner but explicitly prohibited using it to collect funds. Carpenter defended himself by stating he was busking, not deceiving, and was known to fans at Anfield. He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0 in a Championship match, with goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney, and Tom Lawrence. QPR's goalkeeper Alex Smithies' error contributed to Ipswich's second goal, while Ipswich's clinical finishing contrasted with QPR's poor attacking performance. The win lifted Ipswich to 14th, pushing QPR to 15th. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised his team's resilience, while QPR's Ian Holloway criticized his side's mental toughness and defensive lapses.

Wells, 23, scored 373 runs at an average of 28.69 with a strike rate of 138.66 in the T20 Blast last season. He praised the club's positive direction, highlighting the coaches' elite performance environment as motivating for the team.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a 29-12 victory over third-placed Chinnor, marking their second consecutive win. Coach Churcher highlighted the contributions of Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams, noting the team's strong defensive effort with over 70 tackles. Despite the win, Churcher emphasized the need for continued improvement, as the Reds face seven lower-ranked teams and league leaders Old Elthamians in their next eight games. He stressed the importance of building on their recent performance to avoid wasting their progress.

A 28-year-old Bangladeshi man, Nazrul (Nazu), is accused of raping a 74-year-old nun in Ranaghat, India, on 14 March, following a gang attack that involved theft and ransacking. Arrested in Kolkata, he is the sixth suspect detained in the case, with eight identified and two untraced. Previous arrests linked Nazrul to the crime, and police acted on a tip that he was returning to India. A gang leader, Milon Sarkar, was arrested in May, though his role remains unclear. The incident sparked nationwide protests.

The passage introduces an interactive video by Robert Opie, founder of London's Museum of Brands, Packaging, and Advertising, discussing factors influencing UK consumer behavior, such as the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports. It highlights changing brand ownership and rankings, noting the video works best in full screen. Two women were scammed by callers impersonating BT technical support: a 71-year-old from Sandyhills on 15 September and a Stranraer resident seven days later. Scammers gained remote access to their computers, leading to financial losses. PC Siobhan Pellett warned of the risks of cold calls requesting remote access and emphasized never sharing banking details over the phone, as reputable institutions do not ask for such information.

Duffy, 37, has signed a one-year contract with third-placed Championship side Featherstone after leaving Swinton Lions, where he served as Scotland assistant coach. He will lead Featherstone's final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Featherstone's chairman, Mark Campbell, praised Duffy's coaching achievements at Swinton, noting his "remarkable job in difficult circumstances." Duffy, a former player for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, was replaced by Stuart Littler at Swinton.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, accompanied by a medic and a coastguard helicopter, responded to an incident at Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve on Sunday at 12:50 GMT. A rider with head injuries and hypothermia from lying unconscious on wet sand was treated on-site before being airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

A UN conference in Geneva established a global flight tracking system using satellite technology, allocating radio spectrum to enable real-time aircraft monitoring. This decision, driven by the 2014 disappearance of MH370, addresses gaps in current ground-based radar systems, which leave 70% of airspace uncovered. Over 160 countries agreed to use automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) via satellites, allowing continuous tracking. The International Telecommunication Union (ITU) emphasized rapid action, while the ICAO set a 2016 deadline for guidelines requiring aircraft to transmit positions every 15 minutes or more frequently in emergencies. MH370's disappearance highlighted systemic weaknesses, with debris later found on Reunion Island.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age 5 in 2002 and was later found living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland, was identified by the FBI after a college application issue. Bobby, 53, was arrested for tampering with records to obtain a driver’s license in 2012 and is jailed in Ohio with a $250,000 bail. Authorities suspected him of abducting Julian, as he had fled after claiming to take his son to preschool. The boy’s mother was notified of his recovery, confirmed through collaboration with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children.

A fire on 2 March in Duncan Street disrupted train services and caused travel delays. Firefighters investigated the site, and the Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste, citing concerns over environmental and public safety risks. Despite the firm being "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws, the EA revoked its environmental permit, effective 7 August, following joint inspections with Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS), which had visited the site nine times in 12 months. The company, operated by Asset and Land Group, could not be contacted and has until 7 August to appeal. The fire's cause remains undetermined.

The passage discusses two bills proposed by Russia's Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia, tied to the Ukraine crisis. The first bill aims to allow Crimea, where pro-Russian sentiment is strong and many residents hold Russian passports, to join Russia without requiring a treaty with Ukraine, arguing existing laws are inadequate for "disintegrating" states. The second bill fast-tracks Russian passport issuance for Ukrainians, removing financial, residency, and citizenship requirements, targeting Russian-speaking populations. Both measures are framed as supporting "fraternal people" amid a perceived threat, echoing past Russian interventions in Georgia's breakaway regions. The party has also sent MPs, including celebrities, to Crimea.

McLaren, a historic F1 team with 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' titles, and 8 constructors' championships, has faced a decline since 2013, marked by chassis issues and current struggles with the Honda power-unit. Once dominant with partnerships like Honda (1988-1993) and Mercedes, the team endured scandals, including a 2007 constructors' title loss due to illegal data use and a "lie-gate" incident. Despite cycles of triumph and decline, current challenges persist, though Ron Dennis remains optimistic about regaining success through improved car performance and Honda's development. Fernando Alonso's return in 2015 reflects hopes for a revival, though recent results remain inconsistent.

Thomas Baker, 44, from Everton, was shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool's Old Swan area on 27 January and later died in hospital. Three Liverpool men (ages 29, 29, 32) were arrested in connection with the incident. Police stated he was shot while entering his car after leaving Phoenix Gym, where suspects had waited for an hour. A silver VW Polo, fleeing the scene, is being sought, with detectives urging witnesses captured on CCTV to come forward, as their information could be critical.

The passage outlines five online strategies to blend spirituality with technology during Christmas: 1) **Everyday Church Online** offers virtual services with a Star Wars-themed Christmas message, reaching 61 countries. 2) **Guardians of Ancora**, a free fantasy game, teaches Bible stories to children. 3) Viral.de’s **social media nativity video** (6M views) reimagines the story through digital interactions. 4) The **Churches Advertising Network** created a time-traveling ad (250K views) highlighting Christmas’ timeless message. 5) **Next Manga** shares Bible stories via manga, including a nativity version sent to refugees. All aim to connect audiences spiritually through modern platforms.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale reviews a proposal to take over 250 hectares of common land, with backers offering 320 hectares as replacement. Experts conflict over environmental impacts, with Natural Resources Wales questioning the replacement land's value but not opposing the project, while developers claim a "net gain" in biodiversity through nearby habitat improvements. The Planning Inspectorate will recommend a decision, leaving the Welsh government to finalize approval.

Chechen Muslim clerics condemned a 1 April report by *Novaya Gazeta* alleging over 100 detentions in Chechnya on suspicion of homosexuality, with three deaths, calling it an insult to their faith and threatening "retribution" against "instigators." The paper accused Chechen authorities of inciting hatred toward journalists and urged Russian officials to act. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report's accuracy, citing torture of detainees, while Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, claiming no homosexuals exist in Chechnya. The mufti endorsed the clerics' resolution, citing divine punishment for those "slandering" Chechens. *Novaya Gazeta* also noted the detention of clerics and TV presenters, and referenced past killings of journalists linked to Chechnya. The LGBT Network warned of potential ICC action if Russia fails to prosecute abuses.

Investing Solutions, a company based in south London, has received significant housing benefit payments over two years by providing properties for single homeless men, with Fresh Start Housing, a charity founded by Samir Patel, referring clients to both Investing Solutions and private landlords. While neither entity acts illegally, a homeless group criticizes their relationship as exploitative, highlighting that Investing Solutions profits by housing multiple unrelated individuals in one property, maximizing benefit payouts beyond rent paid to landlords. The company, one of the UK's largest housing benefit recipients, claims most rents go to private landlords, but tenants report poor living conditions. Wandsworth Council has paid over £2.1m to Investing Solutions, with the company generating £11,568 annual profit from a single property. Fresh Start Housing states it has housed 788 homeless individuals but lacks authority to disclose figures related to Investing Solutions. Critics, including a homeless charity, condemn the arrangement as prioritizing profit over welfare, though Investing Solutions and Fresh Start assert their compliance and charitable goals.

GB's basketball team lost to the Netherlands in a closely contested game, with Andrew Lawrence (14 points) and Ben Gordon (13 points) leading the effort. Coach Joe Prunty noted his team's lapses in intensity, despite a third-quarter resurgence by Gordon, who contributed a key three-point stretch. The Netherlands, led by Worthy De Jong's 18 points, overcame a GB lead to win, aided by a 10-0 fourth-quarter run. The loss marks the start of GB's Eurobasket qualifying campaign, with Prunty emphasizing the need for consistent effort. Gordon, who missed the 2012 Olympics, showed strong form, particularly in the third quarter.

Conor McGregor submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) for using 8oz gloves in his boxing match against Floyd Mayweather, despite rules requiring 10oz gloves for 154lbs bouts. The NAC will debate the request on 16 August, citing health and safety concerns. Mayweather had previously announced his intent to use lighter gloves, but his team had not yet submitted the required documentation. McGregor, a UFC champion who previously used 4oz gloves, faced criticism but was approved by the NAC, partly due to his performance against Nate Diaz and his physical advantages over Mayweather. The commission advised McGregor's camp to hire a boxing referee, leading to the involvement of Joe Cortez, though a sparring session incident caused a referee to leave the camp. The fight, potentially the richest in history, has drawn scrutiny from boxing figures.

The passage details the decline of Fleet Street as a hub of British journalism, marked by the closure of the Sunday Post's London office. Once the epicenter of national newspapers, Fleet Street was renowned for its historical significance, from the 1702 launch of the *Daily Courant* to its heyday as a career pinnacle for journalists. Personal accounts from long-time reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith highlight its vibrant past, including pubs, typewriters, and a male-dominated environment, contrasted with its current state of sandwich bars and digital shifts. The 1986 move of major papers to Wapping, driven by cost-cutting and technology, accelerated its decline. Despite its end, figures like Robin Esser and Liz Hodgkinson reflect on its legacy, emphasizing its role in shaping public information before television and social media. The closure symbolizes the end of an era, with remaining journalists like Smith and Sherriff carrying its history forward.

J.K. Rowling discusses facing online abuse and political criticism, including being called a "traitor" for her £1m donations to the No vote in the Scottish independence referendum and the Labour party. She blocked users she linked to the SNP, stating she would not silence abusive behavior to protect political reputations, while also engaging positively with some SNP supporters. The SNP won 56 of 59 Scottish seats in recent elections, becoming the UK's third-largest party. Rowling humorously responded to book-burning suggestions and emphasized her stance against bullying on social media.

A University of Edinburgh study found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action and more prone to violence, with poverty exacerbating crime risks as both victims and perpetrators. Poorer youth were five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision, and a history of police trouble strongly predicted disengagement from education or employment by 18. Gender disparities were noted, with boys three times more likely to commit violence and girls from poorer areas twice as likely to engage in violent crime. The research, tracking 4,300 Edinburgh youth since 1998, highlights a cycle where poverty and juvenile justice contact reinforce each other, perpetuating violence. Despite Scotland's overall crime decline, deprived areas remain highly affected, with crime concentrated in neighborhoods facing health and unemployment challenges. The Scottish government cites record-low crime rates and initiatives to tackle poverty, while researchers question whether inequality is adequately addressed.

Mr. Haugh, 25, was stabbed to death in the Marian estate, Kilkee, in the early hours of Sunday. Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm, remanded in custody until 14 August, and faces trial. Two other men arrested were released without charge. Police allege Walsh and two others entered the estate to find Haugh, leading to a fight where weapons were used. Haugh died from a stab wound after being taken to Limerick University Hospital. A blood-stained knife was recovered at the scene. The court noted local tension following the killing.

Phil Flanagan, a Sinn Féin MLA, faced legal action after tweeting in 2014 that Tom Elliott, a former UDR member and current MP, had "harassed and shot" people during his service (1982–1992). The High Court heard Elliott's clear MoD record and that the tweet was deleted within an hour. Flanagan apologized, calling the claim "untrue and without foundation," while an insurance firm refused to cover his costs, prompting a separate legal challenge. Elliott expressed vindication but criticized the delayed resolution, noting the case could have been settled 19 months earlier. Compensation remains under review.

Hawick Knitwear, employing over 230 staff, has boosted weekly sweater production to 9,500 (up from 7,500) to meet rising demand, driven by strong sales of its new branded range and private label clients. The company, acquired by managing director Benny Hartop in November 2022, operates in European markets (Sweden, Germany, etc.) and global regions (USA, Japan). Hartop attributes growth to increased orders and expresses confidence in future success due to staff dedication.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, a lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries in December 2022 after being struck by Brian Wright, 55, who claimed he was blinded by the setting sun. Wright, who denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, failed to stop at a red light while she was crossing Bedford Road with a woman and her child. The court heard the sun's glare may have impaired his vision. Blackburn, now in residential care, was described as a much-loved community figure. The trial continues, with Wright expressing remorse.

The passage describes a NATO anti-submarine warfare exercise, "Dynamic Mongoose," simulating a German U-boat (U33) targeting a U.S. command ship and oil tanker, highlighting challenges in detecting stealthy submarines. It underscores growing concerns over Russia's advanced submarine fleet, including "quietest" subs and technological superiority, which pose a significant threat. The exercise reveals vulnerabilities in Britain's defense, notably the lack of maritime patrol aircraft, forcing reliance on allies. Innovations like underwater drones and long-range aircraft are emphasized, alongside NATO's collective readiness. The scenario reflects broader anxieties about Russia's military expansion and the need for improved anti-submarine capabilities.

The passage highlights the escalating violence in South Sudan, where ethnic conflict between the Dinka and Nuer groups has led to widespread atrocities, including killing, rape, and ethnic targeting. Over 340,000 people, primarily from the Equatorians, have fled to Uganda since July 2016, surpassing Syria's refugee numbers that year. Refugees describe horrific experiences, such as family members being hacked to death or children beaten. Uganda, while initially managing the influx by allocating land and aid, now struggles with the scale, housing over 250,000 refugees in camps like Bidi Bidi. The UN warns of potential "genocide" and "ethnic cleansing," urging international pressure on South Sudanese leaders to halt the violence, which has displaced nearly a million people and left many children orphaned or traumatized.

McKenzie, 38, faces Jahmaine Smyle on 12 November at York Hall for the English super-middleweight title. A professional boxer since 2013 (after quitting football in 2011), he has 8 wins and 1 draw from 9 fights. He is the son of former British/European champion Clinton and trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The passage outlines plans for a new £33m Bridgwater Community Hospital, funded by a £330m coalition investment, replacing the 1813-era facility. The new hospital will feature 30 beds, a maternity unit, minor injury care, X-ray services, and mobile scanners. NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust will cover remaining costs. Matron Sue Taylor highlights the old building's poor condition and the benefits of a modern facility for patient well-being. Three of Somerset's 13 community hospitals have been replaced in five years, with work also underway on a new Musgrove Park Hospital building. Dr. Donal Hynes emphasizes improved patient care through integrated services. The hospital is planned for Bowers Lane, pending approval, with a target completion by autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near Sheffield's city centre, while in or near his black Mercedes. Police found him with a chest wound at 13:35 GMT; he later died at the hospital. Local residents noted he was part of a family hosting a celebration, with attendees attempting to assist after the shooting. The incident adds to a recent surge in city shootings, though previous incidents occurred in northern areas like Shiregreen, Southey Green (mistaken identity), and High Green.

The passage details cyber warfare activities in the Ukraine conflict, focusing on groups like the **Ukrainian Cyber Troops** (led by Yevhen Dokukin), **Cyber Berkut** (anti-Western, targeting Ukrainian infrastructure), and **Anonymous International** (leaking Kremlin data). Key actions include DDoS attacks, hacking servers, leaking documents, disrupting funding, and propaganda efforts. While Ukrainian officials deny using hacked data for military targeting, groups like Cyber Berkut claim to expose Western influence and Ukrainian "genocide," while Anonymous International focuses on Russian domestic affairs. The text highlights tensions between cyber activists, governments, and verified claims.

The passage highlights the farewell speeches of departing MSPs ahead of the 5 May election. Tricia Marwick, presiding officer, was emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond (former SNP leader and first minister) bid farewell. Salmond emphasized Scotland's diversity and unity, reiterated his belief in Holyrood's growing governance role, and critiqued the Scotland Bill for not fulfilling unionist pledges. He humorously referenced the UK budget and Cheltenham races. McNeil warned Holyrood must improve accountability and learn from Westminster's committee system, while Annabel Goldie joked about her interactions with John Swinney. Marwick praised Salmond's service, and McNeil reflected on his 23 years in parliament.

Sarah Rochira, Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is reviewing the quality of life and care for older people in residential care by gathering experiences from residents, families, and staff to inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review focuses on factors like health, social relationships, and care environments, aiming to address disparities and improve standards. While supporting the initiative, Care Forum Wales expressed disappointment that the advisory panel lacks representation from care home experts, citing a missed opportunity for sector collaboration.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported a £3.5m pre-tax profit for the year ending June 2016, a £800,000 increase despite a £1m drop in turnover to £100m. International sales growth in Europe and new markets offset challenges, with the company supplying animal feeds and operating 19 Country Store shops in Scotland. The firm acknowledged agricultural sector uncertainties, including Brexit, but expressed confidence in its resilience.

A 70-year-old man was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, with police treating the death as murder. A separate 80-year-old man was hospitalized. Investigators are seeking 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker), described as white, 6ft tall, with greying hair and average build, wearing specific clothing. Authorities urge the public not to approach him and to contact police or Crimestoppers. Additional patrols are underway in the area.

David Lipton, IMF's second-in-command, warned of a weakening global economy and a "delicate juncture" in a speech, citing China's sharp 25% year-on-year export decline as a key risk. The IMF may downgrade its 3.4% global growth forecast for 2024, with ongoing implications for businesses reliant on China's growth.

The passage details issues with a new chain ferry launched in late May, including breakdowns, groundings, and vehicle damage, leading to a council review and free crossings at Cowes until 2 July. Council leader Dave Stewart acknowledged challenges, while transport councillor Ian Ward described the problems as "teething issues" in a prototype, noting fixes for electrical faults and ramp extensions. Local business owner Angie Booth highlighted economic losses, questioning compensation for businesses, similar to that for damaged cars. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency suspended the ferry over training issues, which were later addressed.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott at 07:30 GMT on Thursday, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, a London-based temp agency, faced criticism for discriminatory job advertisements emphasizing physical attributes, such as a "classic look" and "B-cup," which the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) deemed "appalling, unlawful, and demeaning to women." The 2010 Equality Act prohibits discrimination based on gender, age, or other protected characteristics, with legal experts noting that phrases like "beautiful and attractive" could code for age discrimination. The agency defended its practices, citing client preferences for "first impressions," but campaigners and the EHRC argued this perpetuated outdated sexism. Examples included a "sexy female driver" role and a client seeking a "Jackie O" look with specific clothing sizes. The agency, which serves clients like MTV and Harrods, claimed it prioritizes "attractive" candidates as part of "first impressions," though critics urged it to align with 21st-century equality standards. Legal risks include unlimited compensation for discrimination claims.

A shooting at a Bangalore hostel linked to Pragati Residential School involved Mahesh, an office assistant who allegedly shot 18-year-old Gautami in the head and injured another student, Sirisha, before being arrested. The motive remains unclear, and gun crimes in Indian schools are rare. Mahesh was remanded until 12 April. India has strict gun control laws, though firearms are sometimes used in feuds. A 2007 Delhi school shooting involving students is referenced.

Glaad's analysis of TV shows from June 2016 to May 2017 revealed 278 regular LGBT characters, with transgender representation rising from 7 to 16. However, over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, including notable examples like Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. The study also noted a record high percentage of Black characters on broadcast TV, driven by shows such as *Empire* and *How to Get Away with Murder*. Glaad's president acknowledged progress but emphasized that representation numbers alone do not capture the full narrative. The report evaluated scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series with confirmed casting or existing airings.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his decision to step down ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. A £10.25m public loan to Northampton Town FC for stadium redevelopment and land development is under police investigation for "alleged financial irregularities," with the money missing and the stadium stand remaining half-built. The MP denied wrongdoing, though his party's local executive council reportedly planned to deselect him. He cited a desire for new representation after five years in office.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old Dallas County police officer, killed 15-year-old Jordan Edwards by firing a rifle into a car fleeing a party in Balch Springs in April. Oliver was fired for policy violations and faces murder and four aggravated assault charges; the trial date is pending. Initial police claims that the car reversed toward him were disproven by footage showing it moving forward. If convicted, Oliver could receive 5–99 years in prison, making him the first Dallas County officer convicted of murder since 1973. The victim was described as a respected community member, and his family’s lawyer noted the rarity of such convictions for officers in Texas. Oliver is currently free on bail.

The passage discusses Melania Trump's decision not to immediately move into the White House with her husband, Donald Trump, citing concerns about her son Barron's education. Critics on social media compared her choice to historical precedents, noting only two First Ladies (Martha Washington and Anna Harrison) had not lived in the White House, while supporters called it responsible parenting. The text highlights historical examples of First Ladies balancing family and public roles, such as the Obamas moving early to avoid school disruptions and past figures like Eleanor Roosevelt and Lou Henry Hoover taking active public roles. It also explores the evolving nature of the First Lady's ceremonial role, with some prioritizing privacy (e.g., Nancy Reagan) and others advocating for causes. The summary underscores the debate over Melania's priorities, her focus on Barron, and the White House's role in shaping family life amid public expectations.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), led by Kate Frame, is investigating the initial police response to his call. Police Scotland is cooperating with the inquiry, which was mandated by the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS). A report on Pirc's findings will be submitted to COPFS.

A yellow wind warning warns of gusts up to 75mph (120kmph), particularly west of the mountains, with unusual easterly winds potentially worsening impacts. Affected counties include Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Travel disruptions on roads and at sea are expected, with Telford Road in Menai Bridge closed until midweek after a tree fell, blocking a main route.

The passage details a hockey game between the Giants and Panthers, with key goals from Mike Forney, Mike Radja, James Desmarais, and David Ling, resulting in a 4-3 score. The teams will face each other again on Saturday. In the league standings, Nottingham leads with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers (27) and Belfast (25).

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former German footballer, publicly came out as gay in an interview, marking a significant moment in German football's struggle with homophobia. His announcement received widespread support from teammates, football officials, and public figures, who praised his courage and called it a step toward greater openness. The move followed past challenges, including Philipp Lahm's 2011 advice to gay players to remain silent and the 2007 coming out of lower-tier player Marcus Urban. Hitzlsperger's disclosure was seen as a catalyst for change, with calls for the German Football Association to foster inclusivity and break down societal taboos.

Sidwell, 34, made 32 Championship appearances this season, aiding Brighton's promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. With his contract ending, he seeks a new deal, expressing confidence in the team's ability to stay in the top flight. Brighton, leading Newcastle by four points, aims to secure the league title in their final two matches. Sidwell, who joined Brighton in 2016 after a loan spell from Stoke, has previously played in the Premier League with multiple clubs and believes he deserves another top-tier opportunity. He highlighted his impactful performances, exceeding expectations, and hopes to negotiate a new contract.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1 in a match where Blackpool took the lead through Jamille Matt's goal after 12 minutes, but Colchester equalized via Kurtis Guthrie's close-range finish. Blackpool missed chances to win, including a missed header by Tom Aldred, while Colchester ended with 10 men after Sean Murray's red card in injury time. The game concluded with both teams sharing the points.

A 29-year-old player made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues (Colchester United) last season as they were relegated from League One. Midfielder Reid, previously at Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, may debut for Colchester in their EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa. Colchester lost their season opener 3-1 to Accrington. Latest football transfers are detailed on a dedicated page.

The passage discusses the push for a permanent UK police memorial following PC Keith Palmer's 2019 murder outside Parliament. The UK Police Memorial Trust seeks £1.5m to build a memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum, featuring over 1,400 names of fallen officers. It will include a brass screen with personalized leaf-shaped cutouts for families and honor police sacrifice over 250 years. The government has pledged £1m toward the £4m project, expected completed by 2019.

Manchester United remain 15 points clear at the top of the table with eight games left after a 1-0 victory at Sunderland. Manager Ferguson emphasized focus on upcoming matches, highlighting their 25/30 win record and aiming to surpass Chelsea's 2005 95-point haul. Injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and David De Gea, plus fatigue in Wayne Rooney, will lead to changes for the FA Cup quarter-final against Chelsea. The team credited determined defending for the win, despite a challenging second half.

Mr. Schmidt of Google stated the company paid £10m in UK corporate taxes (2006-2011) and adhered to legal requirements, asserting taxes are not optional. He emphasized that tax changes should be political decisions, urging the UK government to reform its system if it seeks higher payments. Meanwhile, UK MP Margaret Hodge proposed a secret committee to monitor major firms' tax practices, targeting companies like Google, which faces criticism for minimizing UK taxes by routing sales through Ireland. The EU agreed to automatic tax information exchange to combat avoidance, while Schmidt advocated for international tax reform, arguing taxes should align with economic activity locations rather than consumption, and called for clearer, simpler tax rules set by politicians.

The NHS Improvement regulator aims to cut agency staff costs by £1bn by the end of the financial year, down from last year's £3.6bn spend. A cap introduced in October limits payments to 55% above normal rates (excluding senior managers), saving £600m so far. However, NHS trusts are 10% behind targets, and while agency spending is falling, increases in other pay costs remain unclear. The regulator will publish league tables of agency spending and track top earners, citing examples of hospitals overpaying (e.g., £130/hour for a surgeon vs. a £76 cap). NHS Improvement warns of ongoing financial strain, emphasizing the need for further reductions.

The passage describes the Longford Town Centre, once envisioned as a commercial hub, now symbolizing Ireland's post-Celtic Tiger economic decline. Local trader Matt O'Brien notes a gradual recovery for his family shop after a 30% downturn, aided by diversification into children's wear and dress hire. Political criticism highlights the government's focus on water meter investments over broadband and the IDA's failure to attract foreign investment. While the government points to the planned Center Parcs tourism project (pending approval) as a potential job creator, local businesses urge further support, such as free parking, to boost trade. The midlands region shows early signs of recovery but requires more targeted efforts for sustained growth.

The competition concludes on 29 May at the same stadium, featuring eight teams that play each other twice, with the top four advancing to the play-offs. Key stats include leading run-scorers (Warner, Kohli, De Villiers), most sixes (Warner, De Villiers), and top wickets (McClenaghan, Kumar). Four England players—Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen—are participating with their respective teams. BBC Sport provides updates on scores, fixtures, and results.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bag usage since 2013, exacerbating environmental issues as non-recyclable bags pollute landfills and rivers. To address this, England will introduce a 5p charge per plastic bag from October, following successful reductions in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland where similar charges were implemented. Campaigners aim for this measure to curb waste and protect the environment.

A severe wind event in Wales caused a school roof to be ripped off, power cuts for hundreds of homes, train delays, bridge restrictions, and ferry cancellations. A yellow "be aware" weather warning was in effect until midnight on Friday, coinciding with busy festive travel. High winds led to service disruptions, site closures, and the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip. While conditions eased by Friday evening, blustery weather is forecast for the Christmas weekend.

The passage highlights actor Michael B. Jordan's excitement about a new film project, where he will reunite with *Creed* director Ryan Coogler and work with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in the *Fantastic Four* reboot, while Nyong'o won an Oscar for *12 Years a Slave* and portrayed Maz Kanata in *Star Wars: The Force Awakens*. The film, *Black Panther*, is set for a February 2018 release.

The passage outlines the restoration of Alexandra Palace's 1875 theatre and BBC studios as part of a £26.6m east wing project, funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund (£18.8m), Haringey Council (£6.8m), and a £1m contribution from the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust by 2017. The theatre, featuring original decor and stage machinery, aims to host performances, cinema, comedy, and music upon reopening in 2018. The renovation includes a public exhibition space in the glazed east court, transforming the site into a cultural hub. The theatre, previously unused for decades, was originally designed for opera, plays, and early cinema.

Former Manchester City player Milner, 30, earned 61 caps for England since his 2009 senior debut, was part of two World Cups and two European Championships but played just three minutes at Euro 2016. He holds the record for most England U21 caps (46) and scored his only international goal in a 5-0 2014 World Cup qualifier against Moldova.

Marcy Smith and her family escaped a fire at their Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador home, which was destroyed after she burned rubbish in a wood stove—a routine activity. Their dog and cats perished. Son David, awake and on FaceTime with his father, alerted the family, enabling their escape despite the fire alarm failing. The family fled in pajamas, but the community provided support. Smith credited David's quick action as critical to their survival, though he remains unaware of his role.

The passage discusses the potential £200m offer from an energy drinks company for a Premier League club, referencing West Ham United. Sullivan and Gold, who acquired a majority stake in West Ham in 2010 for £105m, now own over 85% of the club. Since moving to London Stadium, West Ham has been linked with Qatari and Chinese takeover interests. Last year, Sullivan indicated a possible minority stake sale to reduce debts but emphasized their intention for ownership to pass to their children.

The passage highlights the 2014 Teen Choice Awards, where *The Fault in Our Stars* dominated with wins for best movie, best female performance (Shailene Woodley), best kiss, and the Trailblazer Award. Woodley honored author John Green in her speech. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for *American Sniper*, dedicating it to Chris Kyle. Channing Tatum (best comedy) and Meryl Streep (best villain) also won, alongside Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, and others. Kevin Hart accepted an award with his children, while Robert Downey Jr. celebrated the Avengers' Generation Award. The event promoted summer blockbusters with clips from *Pitch Perfect 2*, *Trainwreck*, and *Ultron*.

The passage details that 21-year-old Smith, a Scotland Under-21 player, was loaned from Aberdeen to Dundee United in July, scoring five goals this season. He previously made 89 appearances for Aberdeen, netting four times since his 2012 debut. Dundee United manager Jack Ross praised his acquisition, highlighting his maturity and potential to strengthen the team's attack. St Mirren, currently last in the Championship, face Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council is using Jetpatcher machines to repair 145 potholes daily over four months as temperatures rise. Additional staff will address drainage damage from heavy rain and clear gutter debris.

A group of Wood Group contractors, including rigging supervisor Steve Innes, were exposed to low levels of alpha radiation while working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland in December 2016 during pipe equipment shutdown work. They were informed of a radiation issue two-thirds into the task but had been working without proper PPE, leading to cancer fears and ongoing medical tests. EnQuest stated the exposure was below reportable levels, noting they informed the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) and implemented additional precautions. Wood Group emphasized safety protocols, downmanning staff for assessments and supporting an investigation. Unite union criticized the lack of transparency, while the HSE confirmed the incident was not reportable under RIDDOR regulations. Innes alleged EnQuest failed in its duty of care, urging accountability.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a 2007 bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past. The dealer's manager later confessed to trafficking stolen Indian antiquities, including this piece, which was allegedly taken from a Tamil Nadu Shiva temple. Following a 2012 court case and discussions with India's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), ACM agreed to return the sculpture. While no conclusive proof of theft exists, the museum cited the dealer's admission of 150 stolen items. ACM, which bought 30 objects from the dealer, will seek legal compensation for fraud, though none of the other items are believed stolen. The ASI formally requested the return in May.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca at 15.5km depth, felt in Milan, Florence, and other cities, with no immediate injuries or damage. Italy, prone to quakes, recalls the 2009 L'Aquila disaster (300 deaths). The tremor, described as "medium-strong" and shallow, triggered aftershocks, power outages, and school evacuations. Recent quakes in the area last May killed over 20. The INGV noted the event's typical nature for the region. Italy faces ongoing challenges post-L'Aquila, including legal consequences for scientists convicted in 2012 for misleading risk assessments prior to the 2009 quake.

On 8 September 2016, Austin Grant from Sheffield, a 62-year-old grandfather, expressed joy after observing results from growing fruit in South Yorkshire's climate, despite initial doubts about its suitability. The fruit remained unripe and attached to the plant at the time.

Rockstar delayed the release of their open-world game to 24 March 2024 from 27 January, citing the need for additional testing and polish. The company confirmed online heists will launch on consoles before the PC release, with PC screenshots showcasing 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and triple-monitor support. Minimum system requirements were also published. The passage notes that *GTA V* previously became the fastest-selling entertainment product, earning $1bn in three days in 2013.

The passage highlights 76-year-old artist Simpson winning the John Moores Painting Prize 2023 for his work *Squint (19)*, a 7ft-tall painting depicting "leper squints"—holes in medieval churches allowing marginalized individuals to observe services. Simpson, previously shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted multiple times, called his win "very nice indeed." Judge Ansel Krut praised the piece as "extraordinary," noting its subtle, minimal style and emotional depth. The biennial £25,000 prize, established in 1957, has previously honored artists like David Hockney, with Sir Peter Blake as its current patron. Simpson plans to use the prize money for art supplies, emphasizing his investment in quality materials.

The passage reports that the offices of pro-AK Party newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit were attacked by masked assailants, with no casualties. Firefighters extinguished a blaze at Yeni Safak, and police cordoned off the area. Both buildings had shattered windows and bullet casings, with attacks occurring nearly simultaneously 20km apart. No group has claimed responsibility, mirroring a similar September attack on Hurriyet, where pro-government protesters accused the paper of misquoting President Erdogan.

A 24-year-old player, previously under contract with the Stags, has joined Marcus Bignot's Mariners on a free transfer. He spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances, and will officially move to the Mariners on 1 January, marking Bignot's first signing.

The passage discusses Arsène Wenger's potential link to a managerial role despite his club contract ending in summer, while Gareth Southgate, England's interim manager, faces key matches to secure the permanent position. Wenger praises Southgate's experience and decision-making, emphasizing competency over fame. Additionally, Wenger confirms Arsenal will offer defender Hector Bellerin a new contract, dismissing transfer speculation, and notes midfielder Aaron Ramsey's ongoing hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police are conducting a joint investigation with the Health and Safety Executive, and the company is fully cooperating.

The passage details a resolution to a pay dispute involving seafarers on two freight vessels, the Hellier and Hildasay, operated by Seatruck under Serco Northlink's contract. The RMT union alleged some workers earned less than £4/hour, but Seatruck claimed the national minimum wage did not apply to non-UK resident crew. Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement, effective next month, to end the conflict, ensuring all crew receive the minimum wage. Serco, which won a £243m six-year contract in 2012, had previously offered to backdate pay increases, which Seatruck rejected. The agreement requires finalizing financial and regulatory details. The route, heavily subsidized by the Scottish government, involves three ferries and two cargo boats serving the Northern Isles.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May 2023 after an incident at Rockley Park, Poole, six days earlier. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Dickie and his mother, leading to a confrontation where he pleaded guilty to common assault. Mitchell and his mother, Samantha, 57, also confessed to lying to police about the events, initially claiming Dickie had pushed Samantha, then later alleging a "tragic accident" occurred when Mitchell tried to separate them. The couple, in a strained relationship, had been at a bar before the incident. They will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a renowned British songwriter and musician, died in London at 66 after a brief battle with cancer. Known as the "Invisible Man" for his low profile, he co-created iconic hits for Michael Jackson, including *Off the Wall* and *Thriller* (with songs like "Rock With You" and "Baby Be Mine"), and disco classics like *Boogie Nights* with Heatwave. Tributes from figures such as Nile Rodgers, Michael Jackson's sister LaToya, and Mark Ronson highlighted his influence. Temperton's career began with Heatwave after working in a frozen food factory, leading to collaborations with Quincy Jones and Grammy/Oscar recognition. His songwriting philosophy emphasized passion, and his work shaped global music, with *Thriller* becoming the best-selling album in U.S. history. A private funeral was held, with his family requesting privacy.

A team led by Swansea University researchers Dr. Neil Loader and Prof. Alayne Street-Perrott discovered over 450 ancient geoglyphs in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon, hidden by rainforest until deforestation revealed them. These 2,000-year-old earthworks, likely used for sporadic ritual gatherings rather than habitation or defense, were constructed in taller vegetation, making them invisible above the forest canopy. Soil analysis of phytoliths, charcoal, and carbon isotopes suggests human-driven agroforestry practices, challenging the notion of the Amazon as a pristine ecosystem. Instead, ancient inhabitants cultivated economically valuable trees, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of resources, with evidence indicating modern forests may still reflect these legacy practices.

Nick Kyrgios, ranked 12th, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance at the Shanghai Masters. The Australian, fresh from winning the Japan Open, cited fatigue from travel and poor sleep as factors in his subdued performance. Kyrgios also referenced a 2023 fine for a foul-mouthed outburst at the same tournament.

Scientists and charities in Wales are urging the government to expand the HPV vaccination program to include boys, citing its potential to prevent rising head and neck cancer cases. Currently, girls aged 12-13 receive the vaccine for cervical cancer, with 85% uptake since 2008. Advocates highlight that HPV causes 5% of global cancer cases, with increasing head and neck cancers affecting younger, non-smoking men. The Welsh government is awaiting advice from a vaccination committee before deciding on broader rollout, while organizations like Tenovus Cancer Care and Cardiff University's research team push for proactive public health action.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old with gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, documented his cancer journey on social media via "Jak's Journey," amassing 28,000 likes. Despite his illness, he attended a school prom briefly, met football stars, and received awards. His cancer spread, leading doctors to halt treatment. His family shared his story, urging donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, and a charity football match is planned. Jak's positive attitude and resilience touched many, with his mother announcing his death on Facebook.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 in a tightly contested match, with Abdallah El Said scoring the decisive goal in the 89th minute assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda had a disallowed goal earlier, and despite a strong second-half effort, they failed to register a shot on target. The win keeps Egypt in contention for Group D's top spot ahead of their clash against Ghana, while Uganda are eliminated from their first tournament since 1978. Ghana had previously secured a quarter-final spot with a 1-0 victory over Mali.

Lancashire County Council has identified land at the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus (owned by Newcastle College) for a potential railway project. Following a Network Rail study, the plan aims to establish two direct trains to Liverpool per hour, partnering with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council. The site offers expansion potential, highway access, and connectivity. Skelmersdale, a 1961 new town without a railway station, will begin land acquisition, reviving plans for improved rail links. The original station closed in 1956.
Plants were discovered during a warehouse search near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, with police describing the site as an "elaborate grow house." A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old unidentified woman in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, was found with severe injuries after being dragged by the neck through streets, requiring emergency surgery and transfer to a specialist clinic. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old German Kurdish citizen from Bad Muender, surrendered to authorities. The motive remains unclear, and police have secured the scene, urging witnesses to come forward. Both victim and suspect are of Kurdish origin.

A study by Cass Business School and universities of Warwick and Wisconsin analyzed 4,600 workers, finding women ask for pay rises as often as men but are 25% less likely to receive them, even when comparing like-for-like full-time workers. The research debunked the "reticent female" theory, showing no evidence that women avoid requests due to fear of upsetting bosses or stereotypes. Factors like employer size, industry, parenthood, and qualifications were controlled. Australia's unique 2013-14 survey data, which tracked pay rise requests, revealed potential gender discrimination, with researchers noting younger workers (under 40) showing equal negotiation success, suggesting evolving trends.

Oxford City Council has exhausted efforts to find new burial sites, with two remaining cemeteries (Wolvercote and Botley) expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. Despite ground investigations, suitable land has been ruled out due to size, poor ground conditions, high water tables, or usage restrictions. The council remains committed to exploring options but notes that future burial capacity will rely on reopening family plots, reserved plots, and ash interments. The last expansion of burial space occurred in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis (19–22 July), offers an augmented reality app allowing visitors to access online content like videos, band interviews, and event info via signs/posters. Global audiences can also engage with the festival remotely, accessing updates, tickets, and atmosphere. Featured acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, and others. Director Caroline Maclennan highlights the app as an interactive enhancement for attendees and a way to share the festival’s essence worldwide.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, succumbing to a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage" despite no prior symptoms of post-race ataxia. The British Horseracing Authority noted such rare incidents can occur in healthy horses across disciplines, prompting calls for further research. Though Many Clouds had previously shown overheating issues and "wobble" symptoms, he had never collapsed before. Trainer Oliver Sherwood praised him as the "horse of a lifetime," while officials ruled out underlying health issues, attributing his death to an uncommon hemorrhage.

A 15-year-old girl met David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Ayrton, now 34 (Davina), denied raping the teen, though the court heard she attacked the victim while two others slept. The victim, who had only consumed a can and a half of alcohol, recalled the incident clearly. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide in 2023, changed her name in 2012 and discussed her sexuality during the trial. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody for sentencing on 4 March, citing risks of self-harm and non-attendance, and noted she would likely be held in a male prison. Protocols were outlined for her detention, and she had previously disclosed the attack to a care home worker in 2014. The case was described as "unusual" and challenging.

The Serbs lost 6-4 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This followed Djokovic's singles exit to Juan Martin del Potro, after his surprise Wimbledon third-round defeat by Sam Querrey. The world number one (29) later won his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

The passage describes a chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, featuring over 20 international competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, Europe, Canada, and the U.S. Participants use only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, is returning to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old Welsh rugby player, has been sidelined since a serious foot injury in September 2023 during a World Cup warm-up. He is nearing a return, aiming to recover in time for the Six Nations starting 7 February. Currently in a pre-season phase, he expects to resume play by early February after adjusting his recovery timeline with physios. Webb renewed his dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, declining other offers to stay with his hometown region, where he debuted in 2007. He emphasized his commitment to representing Wales.

On Tuesday, U.S. border agents intercepted two men near Sumas, Washington, attempting to smuggle 58lb of MDMA from Canada to San Francisco. One man fled after firing at agents, while Jeffrey Laviolette was arrested. Canadian and U.S. authorities later detained Nathan Hall, who had a fake California driver’s license, and Kali Henifin, who planned to pick up the men. Henifin’s boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, was to be paid $11,000 to transport the drugs. All face conspiracy and drug charges. The area is a known smuggling route, with authorities emphasizing drug smuggling as a key focus.

The NSPCC's Childline reported a significant rise in counseling children affected by online abuse, from 2,400 in 2011-12 to over 4,500 in the past year, with some children as young as seven experiencing severe bullying and fear. Online trolls are linked to widespread misery, prompting calls for urgent adult intervention, including parents, teachers, and schools, to address cyberbullying, which persists beyond school grounds. Dame Esther Rantzen emphasized that bullying worsens without action and urged children to seek help. The report coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, highlighting collaboration with organizations to combat the issue. A young person shared distressing experiences of online harassment, stressing the need for awareness and support, as victims often struggle to cope alone.

The passage details tensions between Israel and the U.S. following the UN Security Council's resolution condemning Israeli settlements as illegal and a barrier to peace. The U.S. abstained from vetoing the resolution, angering Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who accused the White House of aiding its drafting. Israel rejected the resolution, recalling ambassadors and cutting aid, while postponing a settlement housing vote to ease U.S. relations ahead of Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the conflict. The resolution highlights the illegality of settlements under international law, a stance Israel disputes. Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas linked the resolution to an upcoming peace conference in France, seeking a timetable to end the occupation.

The passage details Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday celebrations, including her visits to Windsor's Royal Mail office and Alexandra Gardens, a ceremony for a new bandstand, and the release of stamps featuring four generations of the royal family. Prince William praised the Queen as a "guiding example" of monarchy, addressing media criticism of his own "work-shy" reputation while emphasizing his commitment to duty. Events included a 6.3km walking trail unveiling, beacon lighting across the UK, and a lunch with the Obamas. The Queen, Britain's longest-reigning monarch, has two birthdays, and a republican group criticized the BBC for excessive celebratory coverage.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in an EFL Cup match, with goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew before half-time. Sakho scored his first goal since November, assisted by Sam Byram, while Ayew added a second. Cheltenham, unchanged from their recent 3-0 league defeat, had limited chances, including a missed opportunity by substitute Dan Holman. West Ham, making seven changes after Premier League losses, controlled the game, with Cheltenham's goalkeeper Jonathan Flatt and defender Kyle Storer making key saves. This marked West Ham's second consecutive victory over Cheltenham in the competition, following a 2-1 win four years prior at Upton Park. Cheltenham's exit ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a fatal collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion after Andreas Werner, 46, failed to detect his motorcyclist as he turned his VW Transporter. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving, received a £1,000 fine, and a two-year UK driving ban. The court heard the victim's family opposed jail time, citing a "momentary lapse," while Werner's defense highlighted his remorse and lack of explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British jihadist from London, joined the ISIS-affiliated group Rayat al Tawheed in Syria, where he produced propaganda videos and shared graphic content, including images of violence. Known online as Abu Daigham al-Britani, he engaged in recruitment efforts and portrayed jihad as glamorous. After attempting to return to the UK in 2022, he faked his death via an online obituary and tried to enter secretly, but was intercepted by police. Charged with terrorism-related offenses, he faces up to life imprisonment. Authorities describe him as a dangerous figure who actively chose terrorism, with MI5 monitoring his activities. His cousin admitted aiding his return, and while a murder solicitation charge remains pending, Khawaja has pleaded guilty to four offenses.

Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season as they finished eighth. He has joined Barnsley as their third signing for next season, declining a contract offer from Wrexham. Barnsley's caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praised his pace and attacking style, noting he will fit their play. The move comes ahead of Barnsley's League One play-off final at Wembley.

A series of sealed detergent bottles washed up on Poldhu Cove and nearby Cornish beaches, posing a risk to wildlife. National Trust volunteers are removing them, as a container from the MV *Blue Ocean*—lost near Land's End in May during storms—is suspected as the source, though the Maritime and Coastguard Agency notes no confirmed evidence. The bottles, containing "Vanish" detergent, have leaked in some cases, alarming conservationists over marine environmental impacts. Cornwall Wildlife Trust and authorities are monitoring the area, advising the public to avoid contact with the bottles, while Vanish has not yet commented.

A crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale, Caithness, around 14:00, injuring several people with minor injuries. The road was closed, with diversions via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich route. Police Scotland confirmed investigations into the incident were ongoing.

Dervite, 28, made 14 appearances last season as Bolton Wanderers finished second in League One, securing promotion. Joined from Charlton in 2014, he has 83 appearances in all competitions. Manager Phil Parkinson noted his late-season contribution. Dervite is the fourth player to sign new contracts post-promotion, following Wheater, Madine, and Karacan.

The passage details tensions between the UK's Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) and Labour Party, particularly in the House of Lords. Despite previous collaborations to challenge government policies on EU citizens' rights and Brexit, their alliance collapsed after MPs rejected their amendments. The Lib Dems accused Labour of "conceding everything" and "waving through" government plans, while Labour criticized the Lib Dems for "false hope" and "grandstanding" for campaign purposes. Both parties have historically aligned on issues like education and housing, but current disputes over Brexit and political strategy have led to mistrust, with Labour anticipating "residual tensions" and no renewed cooperation.

The passage highlights that defense is a low priority for UK political parties, with public and political focus shifted to issues like the economy and NHS. Despite global instability, UK defense spending has declined, dropping to 6th globally and below the 2% GDP target, with only UKIP and the DUP committing to maintain it. Military capabilities are shrinking, including reduced armed forces, limited naval and air assets, and reliance on NATO allies. Future cuts are anticipated, with no party pledging to protect defense funding. Trident nuclear deterrent renewal is contentious, with varying party positions, while new aircraft carriers face crew and equipment challenges. Experts warn of a "hollow force" and declining military credibility, as the UK struggles to match its global ambitions amid budget constraints.

FC Barcelona denied wrongdoing in Neymar's transfer, stating they covered potential contract interpretations. The club paid £48.6m for the striker, with total costs reaching £106.8m including fees and taxes. A judge ordered continued investigation into the transfer's financials, following allegations of higher costs. Barcelona made a €13.55m tax declaration to defend its reputation, despite denying tax crimes. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriation but denies wrongdoing. Neymar has scored 10 goals in 25 matches for the club this season.

Michael Luciw, 27, died in a crash when a van he was in was hit by a Mazda driven by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. Newman was driving the wrong way on a motorway. Luciw's family urged regular driving tests for older drivers, citing age-related reaction delays, while Age UK emphasized the importance of enabling older people to drive safely. Current UK rules require drivers over 70 to self-assess every three years without medical tests. The DVLA stated there's no evidence older drivers are more accident-prone, maintaining existing regulations. Luciw's family and surviving driver Andy Harrington called for stricter measures to prevent such tragedies.

The passage discusses concerns over the safety of transvaginal mesh implants used for incontinence, following reports of severe side effects in thousands of women. An independent review faced criticism for a "watered-down" report, leading to resignations from two patients and a consultant. Alison Britton, an expert, will assess the review process and lessons learned. The report recommended against routine procedures, advocating for informed patient choices and mandatory adverse event reporting, though a ban was not implemented due to regulatory constraints. The review chair, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to unify the panel, amid public protests and allegations of compromised findings. Over 20,000 Scottish women have undergone the procedure, with 400 pursuing legal action over complications.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Mary McColgan's 25-year-old British 5K record by 14 seconds (14:49.12) at Glasgow's Emirates Arena. McColgan expressed excitement but initially questioned if the race met UK Athletics' criteria, noting Muir was the sole competitor and raising concerns about drug testing. British Athletics confirmed the time would be ratified. McColgan praised Muir's potential, suggesting she could run faster than 14:30, and compared Muir's race to her own record-breaking effort, which included lapping future star Paula Radcliffe. Muir also holds the British 1500m record and reached the 1500m Olympic final in 2016.

Jung won the event aboard Sam, a late replacement for the injured Fischertakinou. France's Astier Nicolas took silver, and American Phillip Dutton won bronze, while GB's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th. Fox-Pitt, competing 10 months post-coma from a fall, delivered a faultless show-jumping performance but lost medal hopes due to cross-country penalties. Ireland's Jonty Evans placed ninth.

Andy Murray, a 30-year-old British tennis player, defeated Italy's Fabio Fognini 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 in a tense four-set match lasting two hours and 39 minutes, securing his place in the fourth round. Fognini, the 29th seed, had five set points but Murray won five consecutive games to advance for the 11th time to the last 16. The match faced delays due to fading light, with Murray expressing relief at finishing before the roof needed to be closed. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week by defeating Maria Sakkari. Murray acknowledged the challenging conditions and Fognini's fluctuating performance, including an ankle injury and disciplinary issues, while emphasizing his resilience. He will face Benoit Paire in the next round.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014, with police finding patrons still present and alcohol served until 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered closed for three months, and Colleen O'Neill (license holder) and James Thomas were charged with violating liquor licensing hours. A defense cited lax adherence to laws, but the judge condemned O'Neill's "appalling record," fined her £3,000, and imposed a £1,000 fine on Thomas, expressing inability to impose custodial sentences.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionists, emphasized "partnership over domination" in his speech launching the party's manifesto, "Real Partnership," which addresses issues like the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal, healthcare waiting lists, PSNI staffing, and Brexit impacts. The election is framed as a referendum on "incompetence, arrogance, and corruption," with Nesbitt criticizing the DUP and Sinn Féin's tenure in Stormont. He expressed preference for forming a coalition with the SDLP over Sinn Féin but denied regrets over his remarks, asserting confidence in his stance and the party's campaign efforts. The manifesto also includes calls for Stormont reforms and protections for the LGBT community.
